Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing a sweet text from Alex: “Which night should we do dinner? I’m free all week, just want to see you.” My heart warms—he’s been looking forward to this, and honestly, so have I. We haven’t had a real date in weeks, and I know he expects me to pick a night soon so we can plan something special. But just as I start to reply, my headset buzzes. Another call. I slip into my telemarketer voice, only to be met with a furious customer. He’s been with our company for years, and now he’s questioning every detail of the new offer, his voice rising with each objection. My manager expects me to handle this perfectly—no mistakes, no lost sales. I feel my chest tighten. Alex is waiting for an answer, wanting to feel like a priority, but my job demands my full attention right now. I can’t let either down, but I can’t be in two places at once. My fingers hover over my phone, torn between typing a quick reply to Alex or focusing on calming the customer, my mind spinning with the weight of both expectations.
